rename.from: Few questions about the threads used

body: If you have more active threads than the number of CPUs in the system, the performance will decrease. In your case, please set inter_op_num_threads=1 and intra_op_num_threads=1 and disable openmp to make onnxruntime run a single thread mode. You may control your CPU usage by controling the number of python processes active.

I compiled the onnxruntime from source and disabled the OpenMP option. The quantity of threads that each process creates is equal to the quantity of cpu core. So it seems that onnxruntime does not limit the quantity of threads, which may cause the competition. The setting of inter_op_num_threads and intra_op_num_threads actually controls the quantity of active threads.
If OpenMP is disabled and thread_pool_size == 1, as you can see in the code, onnxruntime shouldn't create extra threads, it must run in single thread mode, unless your model has RNN kernels.
Yes, I use the RNN kernels. So it means that there are no solutions to prevent the competition.

I rewrite the lstm code in tensorflow using while_loop and convert it to onxx format, it no longer creates multi threads. Thus there are no competitions between processes. I suggests that adding an option to disable the multi threads even using the RNN kernels. Thanks!
@snnn, any update on the RNN kernels when trying to limit to 1 thread? Was this fixed in a recent release?

If you fetch the latest master, it should work. But the change isn't in the latest release. It will be in onnxruntime 1.3. 

In the latest code, if you don't want onnxruntime use multiple threads, please:
1. build onnxruntime from source, and disable openmp. By default it is disabled, just make sure you didn't append "--use_openmp" to build.py's arguments.

2. SetIntraOpNumThreads to 1, set SetInterOpNumThreads to 1. 
See: https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/master/include/onnxruntime/core/session/onnxruntime_c_api.h#L323
e.g.
https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/master/csharp/test/Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.EndToEndTests.Capi/CXX_Api_Sample.cpp#L17

Thanks @snnn! I've tested the latest nightly build and can confirm that it is resolved. 
```
pip install -i https://test.pypi.org/simple/ ort-nightly
```
Any word on when 1.3 is planned for release?

> Any word on when 1.3 is planned for release?

Sorry, currently it is not scheduled yet, at least we won't do it in Apr or May.

issue.title: Cannot force to single threaded execution

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
By default, `session.run()` uses all my computer's cores. I have tried unsuccessfully to modify the session options according to the Python API [documentation](https://microsoft.github.io/onnxruntime/python/api_summary.html#onnxruntime.SessionOptions) to limit use to a single thread only. Having control over the number of threads will allow easier integration with the rest of my application code 

**Urgency**
None

**System information**
- OS Platform and Distribution: Linux Ubuntu 18.04
- ONNX Runtime installed from (source or binary): source with DNNL provider
- ONNX Runtime version: 1.2.0
- Python version: 3.6.10
- Visual Studio version (if applicable): NA
- GCC/Compiler version (if compiling from source): 7.5.0
- CUDA/cuDNN version: CUDA 10.2 / cuDNN 7.3.1
- GPU model and memory: Nvidia GeForce GTX 1060 mobile (6 GB)

**To Reproduce**
Build with DNNL support from commit a02638eb

```
./build.sh --parallel --use_dnnl --enable_pybind --build_wheel 
```

Install the Python wheel

```
pip install build/Linux/Debug/dist/onnxruntime_dnnl-1.2.0-cp36-cp36m-linux_x86_64.whl
```

Run several iterations of a session with the Python API
```
import os
import onnxruntime

# Adjust session options
opts = onnxruntime.SessionOptions()
opts.intra_op_num_threads = 1
opts.inter_op_num_threads = 1
opts.execution_mode = onnxruntime.ExecutionMode.ORT_SEQUENTIAL

# Check environmental variables just in case
os.environ["OMP_NUM_THREADS"] = "1"
os.environ["OMP_WAIT_POLICY"] = "PASSIVE"

# Create and run session
ort_session = onnxruntime.InferenceSession('/path/to/model.onnx', sess_options=opts)
ort_session.set_providers(['DnnlExecutionProvider'])
ort_inputs = {ort_session.get_inputs()[0].name: ... }  # Add dummy tensor
for _ in range(1000):
    ort_outs = ort_session.run(None, ort_inputs)  # Monitor CPU with htop
```

**Expected behavior**
Only one thread should be engaged when monitoring CPU usage via `htop`

**Screenshots**
Proof of all threads running from `htop` output

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39926682/76796578-fe6d2380-6788-11ea-9897-4bcf969674c8.png)

**Additional context**
I have the same issue when installing binaries from `pip` and using the default CPU execution provider. There seems to be no reason this behavior would be specific to my particular ONNX model

body:
> If OpenMP is disabled and thread_pool_size == 1, as you can see in the code, onnxruntime shouldn't create extra threads, it must run in single thread mode, unless your model has RNN kernels.

@snnn related to this, I saw that in the 1.7.0 release that:

> all ONNX Runtime CPU packages are now built without OpenMP

so does this mean that you can now simply set:
```
inter_op_num_threads=1
intra_op_num_threads=1 
```
and **ONNX runtime will not create it's own internal threads?**

We are having some serious performance degradation issues in an app that appears to be related to this, e.g. load increases non-linearly due to thread contention it seems. With very high CPI.

Additional question, if you build ONNX runtime from source will it default to no OpenMP for CPU?

> ONNX runtime will not create it's own internal threads?

Yes, you are right. You can use your debugger to verify.

>  if you build ONNX runtime from source will it default to no OpenMP for CPU?

Yes.
